Award.AwardTitle: Cholesterol Flip-Flop Dynamics and Nanomechanical Response of Deformed Biomembranes: Experiments and Petascale Simulations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to combine experiment and computer simulation to investigate the relationships between cell membrane composition, organization, and mechanical behavior. The nanoscale response of cell membranes to mechanical stress is an essential aspect of important biophysical processes such as endo- and exocytosis, viral fusion and budding, and intracellular trafficking. The joint experimental-simulation studies conducted under this award will probe how molecular processes such as phase separation into liquid-ordered and liquid-disordered domains by membrane lipids and cholesterol flip-flop across the cell membrane bilayer modulate the nanomechanical response of membranes. Newly developed computational tools include a petascale computational framework to perform multimillion-atom MD simulations embedded in coarse-grained MD simulations.

These studies will add significantly to biophysical understanding of bending mechanics of cell membranes, which has profound implications for viral infection and neuron communication. The educational plan focuses on a dual-degree program in which students fulfill Ph.D. requirements within their own discipline while studying towards an M.S. in computer science. Dual-degree students will help organize computational science workshops for underrepresented groups, which are held regularly at the University of Southern California. The educational outreach plan also integrates high-school students into experimental research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

 

The membranes of cells are formed by two layers (or "leaflets") of lipid molecules organized opposite one another. These lipid bilayers host the membrane proteins that act as receptors, gates, and channels in the membrane and facilitate the cell's interaction with its outside world. However, the lipid bilayer itself also has functional properties that are important to biological processes. These properties include the ability to bend. Cell membrane bending is important to many health related processes: it happens in neuronal synapses during neurotransmitter release; it is necessary for cell division; it happens during viral infection and when viral particles bud from the surfaces of infected cells. The goal of this research project is to connect the mechanics of lipid bilayer binding to subtle molecular motions within the bilayer.

 

In particular, this project focuses on lipid flip-flop, the process by which a lipid molecule moves from one leaflet to another. In principle, this mode of motion should make membrane bending easier, since it allows for lipid molecules to get out of each others' way as the membrane bends. Our primary goal is to observe and characterize the connection between the flip-flop motion and relaxation of the bending stress of the membrane. We do this by combining computer simulations of lipid flip-flop with experiments examining lipid bilayer mechanics.

 

We made two major innovations in working towards these goals:

1. We built the first computer simulation of cholesterol flip-flop in which cholesterol molecules were observed to spontaneously transport from one leaflet of the bilayer to the other. This spontaneous transportation allowed us to rigorously and realistically characterize the energetics and kinetics of the transport process. We found that cholesterol flip-flop is very fast, with a single molecule crossing from one leaflet of the membrane to the other in tens of nanoseconds.

2. We obtained the first experimental evidence of bending relaxation in lipid bilayer membranes. We built artificial lipid bilayers with the size and shape of cells and trapped them in a microfluidic channel. Then, using optical force from two laser beams, we stretched them while recording high-speed video of their deformation. This allowed us to measure degree of deformation as a function of time and to find that at about 50-200 milliseconds after the application of force, the membrane relaxes; that is, it bends more easily. We are working to connect this relaxation to molecular flip-flop.

 

Broader impacts:

As part of an educational outreach program that was integrated with this research program, we brought local high school teachers into the lab during the summer. There, they learned about lipid bilayer biophysics, optical trapping, and data analysis. They integrated what they learned into lesson plans for their students in the next academic year.
